elements.content: Six coordination polymers constructed from three structurally related ligands, 1,2-bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L1), 1,3-bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L2), and 1,4-bis[2-(2-pyridyl)imidazol-1-ylmethyl]benzene (L3) have been synthesized: [Zn2(ODPT)(L1)0.5(H2O)]·3H2O (1), [Zn2(ODPT)(L2)(H2O)2]·3H2O (2), [Zn2(ODPT)L3(H2O)]·6H2O (3), [Cd2(ODPT)(L1)0.5(H2O)]·4H2O (4), [Cd(H2ODPT)(L2)]·2H2O (5), and [Cd1.5(HODPT)(L3)0.5] (6), where H4ODPT is 4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid. Their structures have been determined by single crystal X-ray diffraction analyses. All compounds are also characterized by elemental analyses, IR spectra, and thermogravimetric (TG) analyses. Compound 1 exhibits a two-dimensional (2D) layer structure with tetra-nuclear zinc clusters as building units, and intermolecular π···π stacking interactions link these sheets to a three-dimensional (3D) supramolecular structure. Compound 2 shows infinite chains and is extended into a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular hydrogen bonds. The structure of 3 is built by L3 ligands connecting ODPT-Zn double-chains to a 3D network with a (42·6·102·12)(42·6)(102·12) topology. Compound 4 is isostructural with compound 1. In 5, partly deprotonated H2ODPT2− anions link the L2-Cd 24-membered rings to generate an infinite chain that extends into a 2D supramolecular sheet by intermolecular π···π stacking interactions. In 6, L3 ligands and the ether O atoms of HODPT3− anions link Cd−O chains formed by phthalic groups into a 3D network. In addition, the luminescent properties of these compounds are discussed.

elements.content: Six coordination polymers of zinc(II) and cadmium(II) with 4,4′-oxidiphthalic acid and three different angular characteristic neutral ligands based on bis(pyridyl imidazole) have been synthesized and characterized, and their various structures being affected by different ligands are discussed in detail.
elements.clean_text: Six coordination polymers of zinc(II) and cadmium(II) with 4,4'-oxidiphthalic acid and three different angular characteristic neutral ligands based on bis(pyridyl imidazole) have been synthesized and characterized, and their various structures being affected by different ligands are discussed in detail.

elements.content: Metal−organic extended structures have attracted considerable interest in coordination chemistry and material science because of their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications in functional materials, nanotechnology, and biological recognition. Therefore, rational design and construction of coordination polymers with the intriguing diversity of the architectures have become a particularly important subject. The key factor is the selection of multifunctional ligands for assembling metal ions to fabricate a desired framework and bridging organic ligands for formation of coordination bonds and coordination compounds.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic extended structures have attracted considerable interest in coordination chemistry and material science because of their intriguing structural diversities and potential applications in functional materials, nanotechnology, and biological recognition. Therefore, rational design and construction of coordination polymers with the intriguing diversity of the architectures have become a particularly important subject. The key factor is the selection of multifunctional ligands for assembling metal ions to fabricate a desired framework and bridging organic ligands for formation of coordination bonds and coordination compounds.

elements.content: In the construction of new coordination polymers, multi-carboxylate ligands act as multifunctional organic ligands not only due to their various coordination modes to metal ions resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites to allow for the large diversity in the topologies, but also due to the ability to act as hydrogen bonds acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures. For example, aromatic multi-carboxylates (benzene dicarboxylate, benzene tricarboxylate, 4,4′-oxybis(benzoate), ethylenedi(4-oxybenzoate), 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, etc.) have been widely investigated for constructing novel coordination polymeric framework. In this context, H4ODPT (Chart ) is selected because it has irregular orientations when it coordinates to metals, which may produce various structural topologies, large pores, and different helices, owing to its tetradentate carboxylate arms and its steric bulk.
elements.clean_text: In the construction of new coordination polymers, multi-carboxylate ligands act as multifunctional organic ligands not only due to their various coordination modes to metal ions resulting from completely or partially deprotonated sites to allow for the large diversity in the topologies, but also due to the ability to act as hydrogen bonds acceptors and donors to assemble supramolecular structures. For example, aromatic multi-carboxylates (benzene dicarboxylate, benzene tricarboxylate, 4,4'-oxybis(benzoate), ethylenedi(4-oxybenzoate), 1,2,4,5-benzenetetracarboxylate, etc.) have been widely investigated for constructing novel coordination polymeric framework. In this context, H4ODPT (Chart ) is selected because it has irregular orientations when it coordinates to metals, which may produce various structural topologies, large pores, and different helices, owing to its tetradentate carboxylate arms and its steric bulk.

As well-known d10 metal ions, such as ZnII and CdII, have attracted considerable attention not only because they exhibit appealing structures but also because of their good luminescence properties. On the other hand, organic ligands play an important role in forming different networks and topological structures. In our previous studies, we focused our attention on the construction of metal organic frameworks with metal salts and flexible bisimidazol ligands, for example, 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-yl)butane, 1,2-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, 1,3-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene, and so on. To further investigate the influence of the neutral ligands on the formation of architectures, we select 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole and use different angular skeletons; three exo-bis-bidentate ligands (L1-L3) are engaged in this system. Six compounds with different structures are successfully isolated.

elements.content:
Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. 2-(2-Pyridyl)Imidazole was prepared according to the literature.

Syntheses of L<sup>1</sup>, L<sup>2</sup>, and L<sup>3</sup>

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, then 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (4.35 g, 25 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature being stirring at 60 °C for 24 h, and then poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid of L1 formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield after drying in air. Luminescent spectrum (nm): λex, 320; λem, 356, 500.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Procedures

Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. 2-(2-Pyridyl)Imidazole was prepared according to the literature.

Syntheses of L1, L2, and L3 

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, then 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (4.35 g, 25 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature being stirring at 60 °C for 24 h, and then poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid of L1 formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield after drying in air. Luminescent spectrum (nm): λex, 320; λem, 356, 500.

elements.content: L2 and L3 were prepared in the same way as for L1 by using corresponding 1,3-bis(chloromethyl)benzene and 1,4-bis(chloromethyl)benzene instead of 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene. Luminescent spectrum (nm): λex, 480; λem, 547 for L2, and λex, 330; λem, 360, 506 for L3.

elements.content: Compounds 1–6 are isolated by the same reaction method with stoichiometry different from the starting materials. A mixture that contains all starting materials was stirred for 1 h and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at that temperature for 72 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, and held for 8 h, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1. And then the title compounds were isolated.
elements.clean_text:
Syntheses of Compounds 1-6 

Compounds 1-6 are isolated by the same reaction method with stoichiometry different from the starting materials. A mixture that contains all starting materials was stirred for 1 h and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at that temperature for 72 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C⋅h-1, and held for 8 h, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C⋅h-1. And then the title compounds were isolated.

elements.content: The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000–400 cm−1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. TGA was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 600 °C under nitrogen. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 3 to 60°. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

The C, H, and N elemental analysis was conducted on a Perkin-Elmer 240C elemental analyzer. The FT-IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the range 4000-400 cm-1 on a Mattson Alpha-Centauri spectrometer. TGA was performed on a Perkin-Elmer TG-7 analyzer heated from room temperature to 600 °C under nitrogen. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of the samples were collected on a Rigaku Dmax 2000 X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.154 nm) and 2θ ranging from 3 to 60°. The solid-state emission/excitation spectra were recorded on a Varian Cary Eclipse spectrometer at room temperature.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1–6 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. Some of the water H atoms in compounds 1, 3, and 4 could not be positioned reliably. Other H atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for compounds 1-6 were recorded on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293 K. Absorption corrections were applied using multiscan technique. All the structures were solved by Direct Method of SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques using the SHELXL-97 program within WINGX. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic temperature parameters. The hydrogen atoms of the organic ligands were refined as rigid groups. Some of the water H atoms in compounds 1, 3, and 4 could not be positioned reliably. Other H atoms of water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps.

elements.content:
Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1–6 are listed in . The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1–6 are summarized in Table .

Structure Description of <bold>1</bold>

As shown in Figure a, the structure of 1 contains two kinds of ZnII cations, one kind of L1 ligand, and one kind of ODPT4− anion. Zn1 cation is coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from four ODPT4− anions and shows a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. And Zn2 cation is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two ODPT4− anions, one water molecule, and two nitrogen atoms from one L1 ligand, showing a distorted octahedral geometry. As expected, the L1 ligand exhibits a bis(bidentate) coordination mode and shows a “U-shaped” conformation (). Each ODPT4− anion coordinates to six ZnII cations (Chart a) to generate a 2D sheet () which contains tetra-nuclear Zn4O4 clusters (). The infinite sheet is stabilized by L1 ligands which bridge metal centers in the same sheet (Figure b). Moreover, a 3D supramolecular network is finally formed by linking these layers through the weak π···π stacking interactions between pyridine rings from adjacent layers, with a plane-to-plane distance of 3.20 Å and centroid−centroid distances of 4.26 and 4.33 Å ().

Results and Discussion

Selected bond distances and angles for compounds 1-6 are listed in . The detailed crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1-6 are summarized in Table .

Structure Description of 1 

As shown in Figure a, the structure of 1 contains two kinds of ZnII cations, one kind of L1 ligand, and one kind of ODPT4- anion. Zn1 cation is coordinated by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from four ODPT4- anions and shows a trigonal bipyramidal coordination geometry. And Zn2 cation is coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from two ODPT4- anions, one water molecule, and two nitrogen atoms from one L1 ligand, showing a distorted octahedral geometry. As expected, the L1 ligand exhibits a bis(bidentate) coordination mode and shows a "U-shaped" conformation (). Each ODPT4- anion coordinates to six ZnII cations (Chart a) to generate a 2D sheet () which contains tetra-nuclear Zn4O4 clusters (). The infinite sheet is stabilized by L1 ligands which bridge metal centers in the same sheet (Figure b). Moreover, a 3D supramolecular network is finally formed by linking these layers through the weak π⋅⋅⋅π stacking interactions between pyridine rings from adjacent layers, with a plane-to-plane distance of 3.20 Å and centroid-centroid distances of 4.26 and 4.33 Å ().

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, compound 2 contains one kind of ODPT4− and one kind of L2 ligand and two kinds of ZnII ions. Zn1 and Zn2 cations show similar square pyramidal coordination geometries [ZnO3N2] which are surrounded by two oxygen atoms from different ODPT4− anions, two nitrogen atoms from the same L2 ligand, and one water molecule. Each ODPT4− anion (Chart b) coordinates to two Zn1 ions by using 3,3′ carboxylate groups to generate a 24-membered ring (I), which is connected to Zn2 ions through 4,4′ carboxylate groups, giving a double-chain (). It is interesting that there is a 28-membered ring (II) in the double-chain. L2 ligand adopts a “U-shaped” coordination mode () and coordinates to Zn1 and Zn2 ions in the same double-chain, which further stabilizes the double-chain structure (). In addition, these double-chains are connected by intermolecular hydrogen bonds to generate a 2D supramolecular structure (Figure b).

elements.content: Water molecules in 2 assemble themselves to form a hydrogen-bonded water trimer. As shown in Figure c, the water trimer consists of three water molecules with OW···OW distances of 2.949(5) and 2.893(6) Å. The coordinated water molecule O2W donates hydrogen bond to O3W which in turn donates hydrogen bonds to one carboxylate oxygen atom and O4W, while O4W donates hydrogen bonds to two carboxylate oxygen atoms from adjacent double-chains.

elements.content: The structure of 3 consists of two kinds of ZnII cations, two kinds of L3 ligands, and one kind of ODPT4− anion. As shown in Figure a, Zn1 atom shows a distorted {ZnN4O} trigonal-bipyramidal coordination geometry with four nitrogen atoms from two L3 ligands and one carboxylate oxygen atom from one ODPT4− anion, while Zn2 atom adopts a distorted {ZnO6} octahedral coordination geometry which is completed by five carboxylate oxygen atoms from three ODPT4− anions and one water molecule. The ODPT4− anion coordinates to four ZnII cations (Chart c) to generate a double-chain that includes two kinds of rings (). Two kinds of L3 ligands show the same “S-shaped” conformations (). One kind of L3 ligand bridges Zn-ODPT double-chains to form a 2D layer (Figure b), which are further pillared by the other kind of L3 ligand to give a 3D open framework (). If each ODPT4− anion is considered as a four-connected node, and two kinds of ZnII cations are considered as three-connected nodes, the framework of compound 3 can be classified as a (42·6·102·12)(42·6)(102·12) topology (). In order to minimize the big void cavities () and stabilize the framework, the potential voids formed by a single 3D network show incorporation of another identical network, thus giving a 2-fold interpenetrating network (Figure c and ).

Structure Description of 5. As shown in Figure a, CdII cation shows a distorted {CdN4O2} octahedral coordination geometry which is coordinated by four nitrogen atoms from two L2 ligands and two carboxylate oxygen atoms from two different H2ODPT2− anions. Each H2ODPT2− anion coordinates to two CdII cations (Chart e). Two CdII cations are joined by two “U-shaped” L2 ligands () to form a 24-membered ring (Figure b), which is further linked by H2ODPT2− anions to generate a polymeric chain (Figure c). Adjacent chains are linked by π···π interactions between two imidazol rings with a mean centroid−centroid distance of 3.56 Å (plane-to-plane distance of 3.32 Å) to give a 2D supramolecular layer (Figure d).

elements.content: Structure Description of 6. As shown in Figure a, compound 6 contains two kinds of CdII cations, one kind of HODPT3− anion, and one kind of L3 ligand. Cd1 center is coordinated by six carboxylate oxygen atoms from four different HODPT3− anions, while Cd2 is coordinated by four carboxylate oxygen atoms from three HODPT3− anions and two nitrogen atoms from two different L3 ligands. The geometries around Cd1 and Cd2 centers can be described as distorted octahedra {CdO6} for Cd1 and {CdN2O4} for Cd2. The L3 ligand adopts a bis(bidentate) coordination mode, displaying a “S”-shaped” fashion (). The HODPT3− anion in 6 coordinates to five CdII cations (Chart f). The phthalate group of HODPT3− links CdII cations to form a Cd−O polymeric chain (). And the adjacent chains are connected by L3 ligands to form a 2D layer (Figure b and ). These layers are further connected by ether O atoms of HODPT3− anions to generate a 3D network ().

elements.content: From the structural descriptions above, it can be seen that the neutral ligands have great influences on the frameworks of the complexes. Because of their structural features, L1, L2, and L3 adopt a bis(bidentate-cheating) bridging mode with four aromatic N atoms coordinating to two metal ions in 1–3 and 4–6. Because the different coordination behaviors of L1, L2, and L3, it is anticipated that the structures of 1–6 are various.
elements.clean_text:
Effect of the Neutral Ligand on the Structures

From the structural descriptions above, it can be seen that the neutral ligands have great influences on the frameworks of the complexes. Because of their structural features, L1, L2, and L3 adopt a bis(bidentate-cheating) bridging mode with four aromatic N atoms coordinating to two metal ions in 1-3 and 4-6. Because the different coordination behaviors of L1, L2, and L3, it is anticipated that the structures of 1-6 are various.

elements.content: L1, L2, and L3 with different angular features have important effects on the final compounds. When they coordinate to ZnII ions, they show different N···N distances between two nitrogen atoms from the same neutral ligand in 1–3. Because of the longer distances of 10.986 Å and 10.983 Å for L3 than those of L1 (7.556 Å) in 1 and L2 (5.935 Å) in 2, L3 ligands can act as pillars to connect metal centers from different metal-ODPT subunits to generate an interesting 3D framework in 3. In 1 and 2, L1 and L2 ligands with shorter N···N distances link ZnII ions from the same Zn-ODPT compositions to form 2D and 1D structures, respectively. Unexpectedly, the Zn/L/ODPT4− ratio (4:1:2) of compound 1 is different from those of 2 and 3 (2:1:1). The ODPT4− anion of 1 occupied more coordination sites than those of 2 and 3, and compound 1 shows a 2D layered structure.

elements.content: In this case, 1D (1 and 4), 2D (2 and 5), and 3D (3 and 6) structures have been prepared by using o-, m- or p-bis(pyridyl imidazole) ligands, respectively. In comparison with compounds 1, 2, 4, and 5, compounds 3 and 6 show higher dimensional structures due to p-bis(pyridyl imidazole) ligands with the extendable character. This result indicates that the rational design of different ligands can benefit for the construction of various frameworks. So for a special M(II)-tetracarboxylate system, the ancillary ligands with different angular characteristics have significant effects on the structure of the coordination polymers. In addition, it is a feasible method to introduce ancillary ligands to construct coordination polymers with different structural types.

elements.content: As a tetracarboxylic acid, H4ODPT may be completely deprotonated to give ODPT4− anion, or partly deprotonated to give H n ODPT(4−n)− (n = 1, 2, or 3) anions. Each of these anions may act as a versatile ligand to construct metal−organic frameworks. In 1 – 4, ODPT4− anions display a variety of coordination modes (Chart a−d). Partly deprotonated H n ODPT(4−n)− (n = 1, 2, or 3) ligand may also act as a multidentate anion ligand (Chart e,f). In 5, H2ODPT2− anion coordinates to two metal centers, while in the structure of 6, HODPT3− anion coordinates to five metal centers. X-ray structure analysis reveals that the neutral -COOH is not coordinated. A variety of coordination modes for H n ODPT(4−n)− (n = 1, 2, or 3) anions may be expected.
elements.clean_text:
Coordination modes of H n ODPT(4-n) 

As a tetracarboxylic acid, H4ODPT may be completely deprotonated to give ODPT4- anion, or partly deprotonated to give H n ODPT(4-n)- (n = 1, 2, or 3) anions. Each of these anions may act as a versatile ligand to construct metal-organic frameworks. In 1 - 4, ODPT4- anions display a variety of coordination modes (Chart a-d). Partly deprotonated H n ODPT(4-n)- (n = 1, 2, or 3) ligand may also act as a multidentate anion ligand (Chart e,f). In 5, H2ODPT2- anion coordinates to two metal centers, while in the structure of 6, HODPT3- anion coordinates to five metal centers. X-ray structure analysis reveals that the neutral -COOH is not coordinated. A variety of coordination modes for H n ODPT(4-n)- (n = 1, 2, or 3) anions may be expected.

elements.content: Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent (EL) display. The luminescent properties of zinc and cadmium carboxylate compounds have been investigated. The photoluminescent spectra of free neutral ligands L1−L3 and ODPTA measured at room temperature show the emission maxima at 356 and 500 (λex = 320) for L1, 547, 360 (λex = 480) for L2, 506 (λex = 330) for L3, and 406 (λex = 354) nm for ODPTA, respectively (Figure and ). The emission of the ODPTA and L1−L3 ligands may be assigned to π* → n and π* → π transitions of the intraligands. In comparison with the free ligands, the emission maxima of compounds 1–6 have changed. Compounds 1 and 4 based on L1 show the emission maxima at 388 (λex = 336) nm and 378 (λex = 290) nm, respectively. Compounds 2 and 5 based on L2 exhibit the emission maxima at 376 (λex = 260) nm and 515 (λex = 440) nm, respectively. Compounds 3 and 6 based on L3 display the emission maxima at 387 (λex = 260) nm and 384 (λex = 335) nm, respectively. According to the literature, the emissions of compounds 1 and 4 may be assigned to ligand to metal change transfer (LMCT). The same reason occurs in compounds 2, 3, and 6. The emission differences among 1–3, 4, and 6 may be caused by different neutral ligands and different coordination modes of ODPT4− anions. According to previous research, the observed emission for 5 is neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor LMCT and can probably be assigned to the intraligand (π* → π) transitions because similar emissions are observed for L2. This implies that these polymeric complexes could be potentially used as luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties.

Luminescent compounds are of great current interest because of their various applications in chemical sensors, photochemistry, and electroluminescent (EL) display. The luminescent properties of zinc and cadmium carboxylate compounds have been investigated. The photoluminescent spectra of free neutral ligands L1-L3 and ODPTA measured at room temperature show the emission maxima at 356 and 500 (λex = 320) for L1, 547, 360 (λex = 480) for L2, 506 (λex = 330) for L3, and 406 (λex = 354) nm for ODPTA, respectively (Figure  and ). The emission of the ODPTA and L1-L3 ligands may be assigned to π* → n and π* → π transitions of the intraligands. In comparison with the free ligands, the emission maxima of compounds 1-6 have changed. Compounds 1 and 4 based on L1 show the emission maxima at 388 (λex = 336) nm and 378 (λex = 290) nm, respectively. Compounds 2 and 5 based on L2 exhibit the emission maxima at 376 (λex = 260) nm and 515 (λex = 440) nm, respectively. Compounds 3 and 6 based on L3 display the emission maxima at 387 (λex = 260) nm and 384 (λex = 335) nm, respectively. According to the literature, the emissions of compounds 1 and 4 may be assigned to ligand to metal change transfer (LMCT). The same reason occurs in compounds 2, 3, and 6. The emission differences among 1-3, 4, and 6 may be caused by different neutral ligands and different coordination modes of ODPT4- anions. According to previous research, the observed emission for 5 is neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor LMCT and can probably be assigned to the intraligand (π* → π) transitions because similar emissions are observed for L2. This implies that these polymeric complexes could be potentially used as luminescent materials.

elements.clean_text:
Thermal Analysis

In order to characterize the compounds more fully in terms of thermal stability, their thermal behaviors were studied by TGA. The experiments were performed on samples consisting of numerous single crystals of 1-6 under N2 atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min, as shown in .

elements.content: The TGA curve of 1 shows that it loses the water molecules from room temperature to 241 °C (obsd 9.3%, calcd 9.7%), and then the anhydrous compound begins to decompose. For 2, the weight loss attributed to the gradual release of lattice–water molecules is observed in the range from room temperature to 118 °C (obsd 8.8%, calcd 10.9%). The decomposition of the residual composition occurs from 260 to 513 °C. Compound 3 loses its water molecules from room temperature to 138 °C (obsd 8.8%, calculated 9.4%). The anhydrous composition is stable up to 241 °C. For compound 4, the weight loss in the range of 25–303 °C corresponds to the departure of lattice and coordination water molecules (obsd 10.1%, calcd 10.8%). The removal of the organic components occurs at 321 °C. The TGA curve of 5 shows that it undergoes dehydration in the range from room temperature to 243 °C (obsd 4.0%, calcd 4.1%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition occurs at 250 °C. For 6, the weight loss attributed to the gradual release of water molecules is observed in the range 34–228 °C (a weight loss of 4.0% is larger than the calculated value, 0, probably resulting from the sensitivity to temperature and humidity or a very slow absorbability of the guest molecules from the air at rt.).

elements.content: A series of zinc(II) and cadmium(II) 4,4′-oxidiphthalate complexes with imidazole derivatives with different flexible and angular characteristics have been synthesized. The influence of neutral ligands and 4,4′-oxidiphthalate anions on the structures of the compounds has been investigated. It is found that the different angular ligands can adjust the polymeric structures as well as the coordination modes of 4,4′-oxidiphthalate anions. It is anticipated that more metal complexes containing neutral ligands and carboxylate anions with interesting structures as well as physical properties will be synthesized.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

A series of zinc(II) and cadmium(II) 4,4'-oxidiphthalate complexes with imidazole derivatives with different flexible and angular characteristics have been synthesized. The influence of neutral ligands and 4,4'-oxidiphthalate anions on the structures of the compounds has been investigated. It is found that the different angular ligands can adjust the polymeric structures as well as the coordination modes of 4,4'-oxidiphthalate anions. It is anticipated that more metal complexes containing neutral ligands and carboxylate anions with interesting structures as well as physical properties will be synthesized.

cln_elements.content:
Chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification. 2-(2-Pyridyl)Imidazole was prepared according to the literature.

Syntheses of L<sup>1</sup>, L<sup>2</sup>, and L<sup>3</sup>

A mixture of 2-(2-pyridyl)imidazole (7.25 g, 50 mmol) and NaOH (2.00 g, 50 mmol) in DMSO (20 mL) was stirred at 60 °C for 1 h, then 1,2-bis(chloromethyl)benzene (4.35 g, 25 mmol) was added. The mixture was cooled to room temperature being stirring at 60 °C for 24 h, and then poured into 200 mL of water. A yellow solid of L1 formed immediately, which was isolated by filtration in 80% yield after drying in air. Luminescent spectrum (nm): λex, 320; λem, 356, 500.

Syntheses of Compounds <bold>1</bold>–<bold>6</bold>

Compounds 1–6 are isolated by the same reaction method with stoichiometry different from the starting materials. A mixture that contains all starting materials was stirred for 1 h and then sealed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel container. The container was heated to 150 °C and held at that temperature for 72 h, then cooled to 100 °C at a rate of 5 °C·h−1, and held for 8 h, followed by further cooling to 30 °C at a rate of 3 °C·h−1. And then the title compounds were isolated.

[Zn<sub>2</sub>(ODPT)(L<sup>1</sup>)<sub>0.5</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)]·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

cln_elements.content: The TGA curve of 1 shows that it loses the water molecules from room temperature to 241 °C (obsd 9.3%, calcd 9.7%), and then the anhydrous compound begins to decompose. For 2, the weight loss attributed to the gradual release of lattice–water molecules is observed in the range from room temperature to 118 °C (obsd 8.8%, calcd 10.9%). The decomposition of the residual composition occurs from 260 to 513 °C. Compound 3 loses its water molecules from room temperature to 138 °C (obsd 8.8%, calculated 9.4%). The anhydrous composition is stable up to 241 °C. For compound 4, the weight loss in the range of 25–303 °C corresponds to the departure of lattice and coordination water molecules (obsd 10.1%, calcd 10.8%). The removal of the organic components occurs at 321 °C. The TGA curve of 5 shows that it undergoes dehydration in the range from room temperature to 243 °C (obsd 4.0%, calcd 4.1%). The decomposition of the anhydrous composition occurs at 250 °C. For 6, the weight loss attributed to the gradual release of water molecules is observed in the range 34–228 °C (a weight loss of 4.0% is larger than the calculated value, 0, probably resulting from the sensitivity to temperature and humidity or a very slow absorbability of the guest molecules from the air at rt.).
